description: A large fruit grown on a vine, also known as winter melon, wax gourd, or white pumpkin. It is typically round or oblong, with a smooth, waxy green skin that turns ash-colored when mature, and white, crisp flesh.
seasons: Year-round in tropical climates, stores well
healthBenefits: Very high in water content (about 96%), making it extremely hydrating and cooling.
Low in calories, beneficial for weight management.
Aids in digestion and has a mild laxative effect.
Traditionally used in Ayurvedic and Chinese medicine for its diuretic and detoxifying properties.
cultivationProcess:
Step-by-Step Growing Guide:
1. Planting: Warm-season vine. Sow seeds directly after last frost.
2. Soil: Well-drained, fertile loamy soil rich in organic matter. pH 6.0-6.8. Full sun.
3. Support: Provide strong trellis or support, or allow to ramble on ground if space permits.
4. Watering: Requires regular watering, especially during fruit development.
5. Harvesting: Harvest when fruit is mature (indicated by waxy, ash-like coating on skin) but before it becomes too old. Can store for long periods.
sustainabilityTips: Whole ash gourd can be stored for several months in a cool, dry place.
Cut portions should be refrigerated and used within a few days.
Often used in soups, stews, curries, and famously to make 'Petha' candy in India.
carbonFootprintInfo: Low to moderate (0.3-0.6 kg CO2e/kg), especially if consumed locally.

staticRecipes.name: Ash Gourd Kootu (South Indian Stew)
staticRecipes.description: A mild and nutritious South Indian stew with ash gourd and lentils.
ingredients: 1 cup ash gourd, peeled, seeded, and cubed
1/4 cup moong dal or toor dal, cooked
For tempering: 1 tbsp oil, 1/2 tsp mustard seeds, 1 dried red chili, few curry leaves, pinch of asafoetida
steps: Cook cubed ash gourd with a little water and turmeric powder until tender. Drain any excess water.
Grind coconut, cumin seeds, and green chilies to a smooth paste with a little water.
Add cooked dal and ground coconut paste to the cooked ash gourd. Add salt. Mix well.
Simmer for 5-7 minutes, stirring occasionally, until flavors blend and the kootu thickens slightly.
Tempering: Heat oil. Add mustard seeds; when they splutter, add dried red chili, asafoetida and curry leaves. Pour over the kootu. Mix and serve hot with rice.

staticRecipes.name: Petha (Agra Petha - Simplified Homemade)
staticRecipes.description: A translucent soft candy from North India made from ash gourd.
ingredients: 2 cups ash gourd, peeled, seeded, and cubed (firm pieces)
1/4 tsp alum powder (phitkari) - optional, for firmness
Few drops of rose water or kewra essence (optional)
steps: If using alum, dissolve it in water and soak ash gourd cubes for 1-2 hours. Rinse thoroughly. (This step makes petha firmer).
Prick the ash gourd pieces all over with a fork.
In a saucepan, combine sugar and water. Bring to a boil to make a sugar syrup. Cook until it reaches a one-string consistency.
Add the ash gourd pieces to the sugar syrup. Cook on low heat, stirring gently, until the pieces become translucent and the syrup thickens further (about 30-45 minutes).
Remove from heat. Add rose water or kewra essence if using.
Let it cool completely. The petha pieces can be separated and air-dried slightly on a rack if desired for a less sticky finish. Store in an airtight container.

staticRecipes.name: Ash Gourd Juice
ingredients: 1 cup ash gourd, peeled, seeded, and chopped
steps: Combine chopped ash gourd and water in a blender.
Strain the juice through a fine-mesh sieve or cheesecloth.
Stir in black salt, lime juice, and mint leaves if using.
Serve immediately, chilled for best results.
